title: Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare
author: Wikipedia
content: AI can assist clinicians with its data processing capabilities to save time and improve accuracy. Through the use of machine learning, artificial intelligence can be able to substantially aid doctors in patient diagnosis through the analysis of mass electronic health records (EHRs). AI can help early prediction, for example, of Alzheimer's disease and dementias, by looking through large numbers of similar cases and possible treatments.

title: AI in Healthcare: Examples, Use Cases & Benefits
author: Acropolium
content: AI algorithms can analyze large datasets of medical records, images, and diagnostic tests to assist medical clinics in more accurate and timely diagnosis. This can lead to preventive disease detection and improved treatment outcomes. AI enables personalized treatment plans by analyzing patient data, including medical history, genetics, and lifestyle factors.

title: How is AI being Used in the Healthcare Industry
author: Lapu
content: AI is primarily utilized to increase speed and accuracy in the healthcare realm. Some of the current uses of AI in this field include diagnosing patients, transcribing medical documents, drug discovery and development, and administrative efficiency.

title: The Potential for Artificial Intelligence in Healthcare
author: NCBI
content: AI is used for repetitive tasks like prior authorization, updating patient records, or billing. When combined with other technologies like machine learning, AI can perform healthcare tasks as well or better than humans. AI applications involve diagnosis and treatment recommendations, patient engagement and adherence, and administrative activities.

title: Top 12 Real-World Artificial Intelligence (AI) Applications in Healthcare
author: Empeek
content: AI provides physicians with data-driven insights to diagnose patients, plan treatments, and manage care. AI healthcare apps support radiologists with decision-making and give them more time to interact with patients. AI-based devices can detect irregularities, diagnose heart problems, and notify doctors about potential risks early on.

title: Who pays when AI steers your doctor wrong?
author: POLITICO
content: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) in the medical field has reignited discussions surrounding reforms in medical malpractice, but with a unique perspective. Physicians leveraging novel AI tools to aid in diagnosing and treating patients are seeking clarity on a crucial issue: accountability in case AI errors occur. The American Medical Association emphasizes the necessity for doctors to have faith in AI systems while being shielded from legal liabilities to enhance patient care.
search_term: medical negligence liability for AI errors

title: Artificial Intelligence and Liability in Medicine: Balancing Safety and Innovation
author: NCBI
content: Physicians, health systems, and algorithm designers are subject to different, overlapping theories of liability for AI/ML systems. Broadly, physicians and health systems may be liable under malpractice and other negligence theories but are unlikely to be subject to products liability. Conversely, algorithm designers may be subject to products liability but are not likely to be liable under negligence theories.
search_term: medical negligence liability for AI errors

title: Malfunction, Malpractice?: Who Is Liable When AI Injures a Patient?
author: Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology, and Bioethics at Harvard Law School
content: This episode explores who is liable when AI injures a patient. Is it the hospital? The developer of the AI? The doctor on the scene? And what legal recourse do patients have? Experts discuss the need for a comprehensive approach to address the intricate interplay between technology, medical practice, and legal implications.
search_term: medical negligence liability for AI errors

title: Civil liability for the actions of autonomous AI in healthcare
author: Nature
content: This paper investigates the potential legal problems that might arise if AI technology evolves or is commonly used in clinical practice. It examines whether traditional doctrines of liability can adequately address the liability for the injuries stemming from acts of autonomous robots. The study identifies several models of civil liability that could be applicable to AI-related harm, including strict liability and negligence.
search_term: medical negligence liability for AI errors

title: Can AI Be Held Liable for Medical Malpractice?
author: The Eisen Law Firm
content: AI technology is not a licensed medical professional or even a person who can act negligently. However, this does not mean there is no legal recourse for patients who suffer harm due to AI mistakes. AI technology is viewed as a product, not a person. When a product malfunctions and causes injuries, victims can hold the product manufacturer liable for their losses by filing a product liability claim.
search_term: medical negligence liability for AI errors
